Ellington Board of Education Position Statement
2018-2019 Budget

Ellington is a growing, dynamic town with increasing enrollment when many schools across the state are experiencing a decline in enrollment.

We have proposed a fiscally responsible budget that attempts to add a few key positions to support our growth which include: an EHS technology and computer science teacher, an elementary education teacher, and an assistant principal to be shared across the middle and high schools.

To compensate for the volatility in our special education budget, we intend to create a separate non-lapsing fund with the town to carry over money from year-to-year to help address fluctuation in special education outplacement expenses. This year, we anticipate being able to fund the account with fines associated with non-compliance of outside contractors.

The Board of Education and administration have worked well together to create a responsible education budget for our town.

FOX 61 was at the Ellington Volunteer Ambulance Corps (EVAC) Friday to cover the volunteer Emergency Management Services Agency, the Ellington Rescue Post 512 as well as the EVAC/EMT (Emergency Medical Technician) Class. Ellington High School (EHS) students were in their clinical uniform and were asked questions about their interest in the class, etc. EHS is working in cooperation with the Ellington Ambulance Association to have seven of our EHS students participate in a year-long course that will prepare them for EMT certification.

The story on Fox 61 will highlight that EHS is the first high school in the state to offer this as a UCONN ECE course. The students are excited about the course and have already tentatively arranged a blood pressure screening at the Ellington Senior Center on Tuesday November 7, 2017. The students are very excited for the opportunity. There is a lot of exciting work going on, and the students are doing a tremendous job!

A Twitter account @EHSSavesLives has been set up to provide information about the program.

Contact: The Magic of Communication

Contact is a curriculum based assembly program which explores the vital role communication plays in students' ability to express¹ themselves, work² with others, and explore³ the world around them.

Featuring juggling, mime, and the performance of an ancient Aboriginal instrument, the opening routines are a whirlwind of movement, color, and music. Topics explored in this part of the program: How is music used to convey emotions and tell stories? How can you communicate without speaking?

In one of the many interactive parts of the program the audience learns how to applaud, laugh, and say 'Thank You' in American Sign Language. Later a volunteer from the audience is invited onstage to perform an astonishing feat of magic while receiving instructions entirely in Spanish.

In the final routines Scott uses spectacular illusions to illustrate how innovations in technology, from the printing press to the radio, have allowed mankind to communicate over vast distances in space and time.

Opening Knight Players Present The Silent Sentinels - March 17, 2016

The Opening Knight Players will present The Silent Sentinels by William Prenetta on Thursday, March 17, 2016 at 7:30 pm in the Gordon C. Getchell Auditorium. Tickets are $8 and $6 for students/senior citizens.

The play begins in 1976 with Kate O’Halloran, who is barely in her 20s and not interested in feminism, arriving at the home of suffragette legend and ERA proponent Alice Paul, aged 93, for an interview. Kate, unbeknownst to Paul, has no desire to discuss the ERA but to uncover the truth behind Paul’s tortured illegal imprisonment in 1917, a secret that has remained buried for over 50 years. By revealing parts of her past, told through flashbacks, Alice hopes to achieve her biggest coup in the little time she has left.

The OKP will also perform this play at the 2016 Connecticut Drama Festival at Pomeraug High School on Friday, March 18, 2016.

Lunch for a great bunch
A new program has been developed by Mr. Welch at Windermere School. Mr. Welch recognizes four students in a particular classroom who have been academically and/or socially focused in the classroom environment. Specialized tickets from the principal's office are offered to a specific arbitrary classroom grades 1-4.
